maml:description.maml:para: Binds an SSL certificate to an IP-HTTPS server.
The Add-NetIPHttpsCertBinding cmdlet binds an SSL certificate to an IP-HTTPS server.
This cmdlet does not work if there is already a certificate binding on the computer.
This cmdlet is similar to the netsh http add sslcert command, but the cmdlet should only be used for IP-HTTPS.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the GUID to identify the application.
Specifies the SHA hashing of the certificate. This hash is 20 bytes long, and you must specify this value as a hexadecimal string.

Specifies the store name for the certificate.
This parameter defaults to MY for IP-based configurations.
This parameter is required.
You must store the certificate in the local system context.
Specifies the IP address and the port for the binding. This parameter value should match the format 0.0.0.0:443.
Allows the usage of IP-HTTPS without SSL encryption, if the parameter value is True.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the GUID to identify the application.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.
Specifies the SHA hashing of the certificate. This hash is 20 bytes long, and you must specify this value as a hexadecimal string.

Specifies the store name for the certificate.
This parameter defaults to MY for IP-based configurations.
This parameter is required.
You must store the certificate in the local system context.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the IP address and the port for the binding. This parameter value should match the format 0.0.0.0:443.
Allows the usage of IP-HTTPS without SSL encryption, if the parameter value is True.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet accepts no input objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command binds an SSL certificate with the specified IP port 10.1.1.1:443, SHA hash 0102030405060708090A0B0C0D0E0F1011121314, application ID {3F2504E0-4F89-11D3-9A0C-0305E82C3301}, and store name my to the IP-HTTPS server.

maml:description.maml:para: Disables the currently active IP-HTTPS profile.
The Disable-NetIPHttpsProfile cmdlet disables the currently active IP-HTTPS profile.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables the currently active IP-HTTPS profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables an IP-HTTPS configuration profile.
The Enable-NetIPHttpsProfile cmdlet enables an IP-HTTPS configuration profile. Only one configuration can be active at a time.
An active configuration does not mean that IP-HTTPS is active. The active configuration may disable IP-HTTPS.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the name of the profile to enable.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

This cmdlet accepts no input objects.
This cmdlet returns an object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables the IP-HTTPS configuration profile named Redmond.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the IP-HTTPS configuration from a computer or a Group Policy Object (GPO).
The Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet gets the IP-HTTPS configuration from a computer or a Group Policy Object (GPO).
You can also use Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration to retrieve the IP-HTTPS configuration, and then use the configuration information as input into other cmdlets.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the policy store from which to get the configuration. The default store is ActiveStore.
Valid values for this parameter are:
-- ActiveStore
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
To get the configuration of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Filters the objects retrieved by the profile name.
Filters the objects retrieved by profile status.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session from which to get the configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Filters the objects retrieved by the profile name.
Filters the objects retrieved by profile status.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session from which to get the configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.

Specifies the policy store from which to get the configuration. The default store is ActiveStore.
Valid values for this parameter are:
-- ActiveStore
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
To get the configuration of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Filters the objects retrieved by the profile name.
Filters the objects retrieved by profile status.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
This cmdlet accepts no input objects.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.
This cmdlet returns one or more IP-HTTPS configuration objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the IP-HTTPS configuration from a computer or a GPO.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an IP-HTTPS configuration.
The New-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet creates an IP-HTTPS configuration.
This cmdlet can create IP-HTTPS configurations on the ActiveStore, PersistentStore, or Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

Specifies the policy store to which to add the configuration profile. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- ActiveStore
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
To add the configuration profile to a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the authentication mode of the IP-HTTPS configuration. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None: Performs no client authentication during the SSL handshake. This is the default value.
-- Certificates: Uses client certificates to authenticate clients. This authentication mode applies only to a server interface on a computer running Windows Server® 2012.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name by which to identify the IP-HTTPS configuration profile. This option is only available if the store is a GPO.

Specifies the state behavior of IP-HTTPS. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Default:
---- For a server interface, IP-HTTPS is always configured.
---- For a client interface, IP-HTTPS is configured on-demand based on the other connectivity options available. Client interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Enabled: IP-HTTPS is always configured, for both server interfaces and client interfaces. Server interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Disabled: Disables the IP-HTTPS interface.
-- OutsideEnabled: IP-HTTPs is configured on-demand whenever the computer is outside of the corporate network.

Indicates if a strong certificate revocation list (CRL) check is required before a connection.
By default, the value of this parameter is False.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies if IP-HTTPS should start in server mode or client mode. Server mode is only allowed on Windows Server 2012.

Specifies the URL for the server. If the profile is a client profile, Windows Server 2012 attempts to connect to the server URL. If the profile is a server profile, then this is the URL on which the server listens.
Specify the server URL using the following format: https://myserver/IPHTTPS
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Specifies the Group Policy session in which to store the configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the authentication mode of the IP-HTTPS configuration. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None: Performs no client authentication during the SSL handshake. This is the default value.
-- Certificates: Uses client certificates to authenticate clients. This authentication mode applies only to a server interface on a computer running Windows Server® 2012.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name by which to identify the IP-HTTPS configuration profile. This option is only available if the store is a GPO.

Specifies the state behavior of IP-HTTPS. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Default:
---- For a server interface, IP-HTTPS is always configured.
---- For a client interface, IP-HTTPS is configured on-demand based on the other connectivity options available. Client interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Enabled: IP-HTTPS is always configured, for both server interfaces and client interfaces. Server interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Disabled: Disables the IP-HTTPS interface.
-- OutsideEnabled: IP-HTTPs is configured on-demand whenever the computer is outside of the corporate network.

Indicates if a strong certificate revocation list (CRL) check is required before a connection.
By default, the value of this parameter is False.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies if IP-HTTPS should start in server mode or client mode. Server mode is only allowed on Windows Server 2012.

Specifies the URL for the server. If the profile is a client profile, Windows Server 2012 attempts to connect to the server URL. If the profile is a server profile, then this is the URL on which the server listens.
Specify the server URL using the following format: https://myserver/IPHTTPS
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

-- Certificates: Uses client certificates to authenticate clients. This authentication mode applies only to a server interface on a computer running Windows Server® 2012.

Specify the server URL using the following format: https://myserver/IPHTTPS

Specifies the state behavior of IP-HTTPS. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Default:
---- For a server interface, IP-HTTPS is always configured.
---- For a client interface, IP-HTTPS is configured on-demand based on the other connectivity options available. Client interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Enabled: IP-HTTPS is always configured, for both server interfaces and client interfaces. Server interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Disabled: Disables the IP-HTTPS interface.
-- OutsideEnabled: IP-HTTPs is configured on-demand whenever the computer is outside of the corporate network.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an IP-HTTPS configuration named Redmond with the specified server URL https://contoso.com:443/IPHTTPs in the GPO named TestGPO.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes all of the IP-HTTPS certificate bindings.
The Remove-NetIPHttpsCertBinding cmdlet removes all of the certificate bindings on the computer. This cmdlet is similar to netsh http delete sslcert command.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet accepts no input objects.
This cmdlet returns an object that contains information about an IP-HTTPS certificate binding.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes all of the IP-HTTPS certificate bindings.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an IP-HTTPS configuration profile.
The Remove-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet removes an IP-HTTPS configuration profile from a specified store.
You can specify the IP-HTTPS configuration profile to remove either by using a configuration object retrieved by the Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet or by specifying the profile name.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session from which to remove the configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a Group Policy Object (GPO).
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store from which to remove the configuration profile. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- ActiveStore
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
To remove the configuration profile from a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with GPOSession.
Specifies the profile name of the IP-HTTPS profile to remove.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies an object which contains the IP-HTTPS profile to remove.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet accepts no input objects.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.
When the Passthru parameter is specified, this cmdlet outputs a modified IP-HTTPS configuration object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the IP-HTTPS configuration profile named Profile1 from a GPO.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Remove a profile using configuration object

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the configuration profile object with profile named profile2 on a GPO using the Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet, and then provides the object as input to this cmdlet using the pipeline operator.

maml:description.maml:para: Renames an IP-HTTPS profile.
The Rename-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet renames an IP-HTTPS profile, either on a computer or in a Group Policy Object (GPO).

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the configuration profile to rename. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- GPO
To rename the configuration profile of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Specifies the name of the profile to rename.
Specifies which profile to rename.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the new name for the IP-HTTPS profile.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Rename an IP-HTTPS profile using a configuration object

dev:remarks.maml:para: This set of commands uses the Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet to get an IP-HTTPS configuration object and stores it in a variable named $config. The contents of the variable are then passed to this cmdlet.
This command renames the IP-HTTPS profile named Redmond to Fareast.

maml:description.maml:para: Resets the IP-HTTPS configuration elements in a Group Policy Object (GPO).
The Reset-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet resets the IP-HTTP configuration elements in a Group Policy Object (GPO) to the not configured state.
Group Policy settings have one of the following three states: not configured, enabled, or disabled.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.
Resets the authentication mode to not configured.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the IP-HTTPS configuration to reset. For this cmdlet, this parameter only supports GPO stores.
To reset an IP-HTTPS configuration stored in a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Specifies the name of the IP-HTTPS configuration profile to reset.
Filters the objects to reset.
Resets the state of the IP-HTTPS configuration to not configured.
Resets the strong certificate revocation list (CRL) check configuration to not configured.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session that contains the IP-HTTPS configuration information to reset.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This set of commands gets the IP-HTTPS configuration using the Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet, stores it in a variable named $config and then passes the contents of the variable to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies an IP-HTTPS configuration.
The Set-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet modifies an IP-HTTPS configuration.
You can specify the IP-HTTPS configuration profile to modify either by using a configuration object retrieved by the Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet or by specifying the profile name.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the authentication mode. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None: Performs no client authentication during the SSL handshake. This is the default value.
-- Certificates: Uses client certificates to authenticate clients. This authentication mode applies only to a server interface on a computer running Windows Server® 2012.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the IP-HTTPS configuration profile to set. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- ActiveStore
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
To set the configuration profile of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Specifies the name of the profile to modify. This parameter is only allowed when the store is a GPO.
Filters the objects to modify.

Specifies the URL for the server. If the profile is a client profile, Windows attempts to connect to the server URL. If the profile is a server profile, then this is the URL to which the server listens.

Specifies the state behavior of IP-HTTPS. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Default:
---- For a server interface, IP-HTTPS is always configured.
---- For a client interface, IP-HTTPS is configured on demand based on the other connectivity options available. Client interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Enabled: IP-HTTPS is always configured, for both server interfaces and client interfaces. Server interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Disabled: Disables the IP-HTTPS interface.
-- OutsideEnabled: IP-HTTPs is configured on demand whenever the computer is outside of the corporate network.

Determines if a strong certificate revocation list (CRL) check is required before connection.
The default value is False.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies if IP-HTTPS should start in server mode or client mode. The parameter value set to server mode is only allowed on Windows Server 2012.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

-- Certificates: Uses client certificates to authenticate clients. This authentication mode applies only to a server interface on a computer running Windows Server® 2012.

-- Default:
---- For a server interface, IP-HTTPS is always configured.
---- For a client interface, IP-HTTPS is configured on demand based on the other connectivity options available. Client interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Enabled: IP-HTTPS is always configured, for both server interfaces and client interfaces. Server interfaces are created with this setting by default.
-- Disabled: Disables the IP-HTTPS interface.
-- OutsideEnabled: IP-HTTPs is configured on demand whenever the computer is outside of the corporate network.

Determines if a strong certificate revocation list (CRL) check is required before connection.
The default value is False.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the server URL of the profile

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command modifies the profile named Redmond in the GPO named TestGPO, modifying the server URL.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set the server URL using IP-HTTPS configuration object
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration -Profile Redmond -PolicyStore Domain\TestGPO | Set-NetIPHttpsConfiguration -ServerURL https://da.com:443/IPHTTPs

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the IP-HTTPS configuration profile named Redmond in the GPO named TestGPO using the Get-NetIPHttpsConfiguration cmdlet, and then provides the output object as input to this cmdlet using the pipeline operator.
